sense.name: (cause or permit) to fall to the ground
sense.examples: Don't drop the dishes. Bombs are dropping on London! The branch dropped with a big thud. The chef dropped bits of chocolate across the cake.

sense.name: move to a lower position, terminate something
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[topic] DROP PP[directional] Note: PP may indicate a metaphorical location.
sense.examples: Utility stocks have dropped again for the second week in a row. Drop to your knees and give me twenty pushups! His voice has dropped since the onset of puberty. He was dropped from the Republican ticket. Mary has dropped all charges against him. I dropped him from the club because he wouldn't pay dues. John is trying to drop his image as a bossy manager. Let's drop the pretenses, shall we?

sense.name: discourse utterance
sense.examples: Can you at least drop me a hint? She dropped a real zinger at lunch.

sense.name: unload or disembark something
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] DROP NP2[patient{concrete]] PP{P NP[location]}
sense.examples: They dropped the passengers at the terminal. Just drop me at the corner. She dropped the packages at the front desk.

sense.name: lose a game in sports
sense.examples: The Giants dropped 11 of their first 13.

sense.name: expend or pay money
sense.examples: he dropped a wad on that diamond necklace. I'm dropping big bucks these days at the casinos.

sense.name: be suspended so as to hang freely
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[topic] DROP PP[location] Note: usually in past tense, rarely in progressive.
sense.examples: The light dropped from the ceiling. Clusters of berries dropped heavily from the slender branches.

sense.name: omit, leave out or miss something
sense.examples: His sentences were hard to read because he had dropped the commas. I think you are really dropping an opportunity here.

sense.name: change to a different state or characteristic
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] DROP PP(into) NP2[attributive] Note: PP always has 'into' as preposition.
sense.examples: She dropped into navy jargon with her buddies at the class reunion. He has dropped into his usual pattern of procrastination. The discussion at Town Meeting dropped into a rude shouting match. Donnie's condition dropped (worsened) as time went on. Let's shop till we drop! The contestants dropped like flies.

sense.name: to give birth, especially animals
sense.examples: The cow dropped her calf this morning.

sense.name: Golf terminology - to deposit ball on the course
sense.examples: Measure two club lengths from the unplayable lie, drop a ball and play from there. When you drop a ball, stand erect, hold your arm out straight and drop it.

sense.name: take (a drug, especially LSD) by mouth.
sense.examples: He was dropping almost every afternoon in those days. She dropped acid behind the barn.

sense.name: move to the rear, retreat
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP BACK; DROP BEHIND; DROP OFF
sense.examples: Ralston dropped back to twelfth after stumbling on a rock. She found her companions tedious and dropped behind to avoid conversing with them.

sense.name: diminish or get worse
sense.examples: The number of students enrolled in the class dropped off after the first week. His grades have dropped off since Christmas. The scores dropped away from last year's high.

sense.name: visit informally
sense.examples: I'll drop by tomorrow with the photos. She always drops in at the most inopportune times.

sense.name: give up, abandon
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP BY THE WAYSIDE; DROP OUT
sense.examples: Her profound confidence kept her going when other women would have dropped by the wayside. After the poll results, Wilson dropped out of the election. Even traditional values like quality assurance are dropped by the wayside during this phase. We should not allow visual talent to be dropped by the wayside just because of verbal deficiencies.

sense.name: leave school
sense.examples: Sandra dropped out her sophmore year.

sense.name: leave, unload
sense.examples: I'll drop you off at the corner.

sense.name: fall asleep
sense.examples: He dropped off the minute his head hit the pillow.

sense.name: DROP OPEN: open involuntarily
sense.examples: His jaw dropped open at the sight.

sense.name: DROP DOWN: fall to a lower level
sense.examples: The coach told him to drop down and give him twenty.

sense.name: multiword expression
sense.commentary: Includes: DROP A LINE; DROP ANCHOR; DROP DEAD
sense.examples: Drop me a line when you get to Berlin. The ship dropped anchor in Witma Bay. He dropped dead of a heart attack.
